history.content:
Even though 16AB are listed as prereqs, I think you'll be fine as long as your linear algebra background is adequately strong (did well in 54 maybe?). 127 is more of a math class than EE/CS so mathematical maturity in the related topics is all you need.

Other classes for 189 preparation: EE 16AB, CS 70, Math 53, EECS 126, Math 110.

- - - - -

+1 to previous student response.  You don't really need EE16A/B for EECS127; certainly none of the circuits or control theory topics.  What is relevant from 16A/B are linear algebra fundamentals, least squares, SVD/PCA, and perhaps k-means clustering (not really).  If you did well in Math 54, that should give you the linear algebra fundamentals.  Perhaps you want to self-study SVD/PCA and least squares, if you haven't had exposure.  I did feel disadvantaged going into EECS127 without knowing SVD/PCA, so I would recommend getting that down beforehand.  That said, Prof. El Ghaoui does teach SVD from bottom up, so if you're mathematically mature, you should be fine going in with just Math 54.

Even though 16AB are listed as prereqs, I think you'll be fine as long as your linear algebra background is adequately strong (did well in 54 maybe?). 127 is more of a math class than EE/CS so mathematical maturity in the related topics is all you need.

Other classes for 189 preparation: EE 16AB, CS 70, Math 53, EECS 126, Math 110.

Read some posts about EE127's material on optimization being critical for CS 189 and data science in general. However, the class needs both 16A and 16B. As someone who has just taken Math 54, what do you think are alternatives to EE 127?

What other classes do people usually take to prepare themselves adequately for CS 189?
history.subject: EE 127 alternatives for people who haven't taken 16A/16B.
